title: Using Google Colab for This Course
text:
Google Colab is a free, cloud-based environment for running Python notebooks.
You can use it from any computer without installing Python locally. It is especially helpful if:

Your computer cannot install packages reliably

You are troubleshooting your Python installation

You want quick access to a working Python environment

This guide explains how to open Colab, upload or access notebooks, install packages, work with files, and download your work.

title: Using Google Colab for This Course
text:
Temporary Upload
from google.colab import files
uploaded = files.upload()

title: Using Google Colab for This Course
text:
Mount Google Drive
from google.colab import drive
drive.mount('/content/drive')
Your Drive will appear at:
/content/drive/MyDrive/

title: Installing the Course Requirements and Checking Your Environment
text:
This guide will walk you through:

Downloading the course requirements file

Using the terminal / command line to navigate to your course folder

Installing the required Python packages with pip install -r requirements.txt

Running a small Python script to confirm that everything is set up correctly

By the end of this guide, your Python environment should be ready for the rest of the semester.

title: Installing the Course Requirements and Checking Your Environment
text:
1.1 — Download the files

Go to the location where your instructor has shared the files.

Download requirements.txt.

Download check_environment.py.

title: Installing the Course Requirements and Checking Your Environment
section: 1.2 — Save them to your Week 1 folder
text:
1.2 — Save them to your Week 1 folder
Save both files in:
AI_Course/week01/
So your folder structure looks like:
AI_Course/
  week01/
    requirements.txt
    check_environment.py
  week02/
  ...

title: Installing the Course Requirements and Checking Your Environment
text:
Windows (VS Code recommended)

Open VS Code.

Click File → Open Folder… → select AI_Course/week01/.

Go to View → Terminal.

title: Installing the Course Requirements and Checking Your Environment
text:
macOS / Linux

Open Terminal.

Use cd to navigate to your Week 1 folder (see next step).

title: Foundations of Analytics & AI
text:
Welcome to the online textbook for the course. It is organized to provide a clear, structured pathway through the foundational ideas and practical techniques of analytics and artificial intelligence. Each week’s chapter includes:

An explaination of the key/core concepts and our objectives for the week.

Demonstrations (where applicable) and worked examples

Links to downloadable code associated with the topics in the lectures.

Practice sections and applied exercises

Short conceptual notes to reinforce key ideas

This site is designed to complement the in-class experience while remaining accessible for self-study. All materials can be viewed online and code files can be downloaded from the course repository. The code in github and on Canvas is the same. The data for this course is stored in Canvas.

title: Foundations of Analytics & AI
text:
How to Use This Textbook
The material is organized into three types:

1. Weekly Modules
These chapters follow the course schedule and lectures. The readings from the text are not identical to the lectures, but they are close. The readings introduce new concepts, connect them to analytics and AI practice, and provide examples to run independently.
Start here:

Week 1 – What is Analytics & AI?

Week 2 – Python Basics

Week 3 – Data Structures & Pandas

Week 4 – From Data to Models





2. Practical Guides (Task-Oriented Documentation)
These pages provide focused instructions for installing tools, configuring environments, and resolving common issues.

How to Install Python

Installing the Course requirements.txt

Using Google Colab

These guides remain relevant throughout the semester and may be updated as tools evolve.

title: Foundations of Analytics & AI
text:
Course Learning Philosophy
This textbook is built around two related objectives:

AI Literacy: developing conceptual understanding of modern analytics and AI systems. How they work, where they succeed, and where they sometimes fail.

Job-Relevant Skills: Translating these concepts into practical, executable workflows using Python and contemporary tools.

Each week reinforces both trajectories: one conceptual, one applied.

title: Foundations of Analytics & AI
text:
Accessing Code and Data
All example code for the course is maintained in the main GitHub repository:

Code folder: code/ (available in GitHub and Canvas) Data folder: data/ (available in Canvas only)

You may download the entire repository as a .zip file or clone it directly.
Links to specific scripts and notebooks appear at the end of each week’s chapter.

title: Foundations of Analytics & AI
text:
Need Help?
If you encounter technical issues with installation, environments, or package setup, consult the Guides section using the navigation bar above. These pages provide step-by-step instructions tailored for this course.

title: Setting Up Python
text:
This document will walk you through the steps to:

Install Python 3

Install Visual Studio Code (VS Code)

Configure VS Code to run .py files

Verify that everything is working correctly

You only need to complete this setup once on your computer.
After that, you will be able to run all course examples and labs.






Tip



If you get stuck at any point:
Installing this should be straightforward. LLMs can be a great way to problem solve an install. Use UFs Navigator Chat to help you. There is an optional video on this in the course files. Still stuck? Reach out to a TA and let them help you out. Use the course guidelines for how to ask good questions to request help.

title: Setting Up Python
text:
On Windows?

Open the Start Menu.

Type cmd and press Enter to open the Command Prompt.

In the black window, type:

py --version
or
python --version

Press Enter.


If you see something like Python 3.10.11, Python 3 is already installed.

If you see an error or a much older version (like Python 2.x), you should install a current version.
Most MAC’s will have Python installed, but this is for your system, you want to install it again. We don’t want to be making changes to the factory installed Python.

title: Setting Up Python
text:
on macOS?

Open Terminal (Spotlight → type Terminal).

Type:

python3 --version

Press Enter.


If you see Python 3.x.x, you have Python 3.

For the most part, you should install a new version, even if you see this.

title: Setting Up Python
text:
on Linux?

Open a terminal.

Type:

python3 --version

Press Enter.

If Python 3 is not installed, follow the installation steps below.

title: Setting Up Python
text:
Windows Installation

Click Download Python 3.x.x for Windows.

Run the installer (python-3.x.x.exe) after it downloads.

On the first screen:

Check the box that says:
“Add Python 3.x to PATH”

Then click “Install Now”.

Wait for the installation to finish.

Click “Close” when done.


Verify Python on Windows
Open Command Prompt again and type:
py --version
or
python --version
You should now see Python 3.x.x.
If you don’t, restart your computer and try again.

title: Setting Up Python
text:
macOS Installation

On https://www.python.org/downloads/, choose “Download Python 3.x.x for macOS”.

Open the downloaded .pkg file.

Follow the installer prompts and accept the defaults.


Verify Python on macOS
Open Terminal and type:
python3 --version
You should see Python 3.x.x.
If you don’t, log out and back in, or restart your machine.

title: Setting Up Python
text:
Linux Installation (brief)
On many Linux distributions, Python 3 is already installed.
If not, you can install it with your package manager. For example:

Ubuntu / Debian:
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install python3 python3-pip
Fedora:
sudo dnf install python3 python3-pip

After installation, check:
python3 --version

title: Setting Up Python
text:
Download and Install VS Code

Go to: https://code.visualstudio.com/

Click Download for your operating system (Windows, macOS, or Linux).

Run the installer and accept the defaults.

title: Setting Up Python
section: Install the Python Extension in VS Code
text:
Install the Python Extension in VS Code

Open VS Code.

On the left sidebar, click the Extensions icon (four squares).

In the search bar, type: Python.

Find the extension published by Microsoft (it should be at the top).

Click Install.

VS Code will now understand and support Python files.

title: Setting Up Python
section: Running the Script (VS Code Integrated Terminal)
text:
Running the Script (VS Code Integrated Terminal)

In VS Code, open the Terminal:

View → Terminal, or

Press Ctrl+` (Windows/Linux)

Press Ctrl+Shift+` (macOS, depending on keybindings)

Make sure the terminal is using the correct folder. You should see a path that ends with week01.
Type one of the following commands and press Enter:

On Windows:
py test_setup.py
or
python test_setup.py
On macOS/Linux:
python3 test_setup.py

You should see:

Python is working, awesome!
If you see that message, your environment is ready.

title: Setting Up Python
text:
“Python is not recognized” on Windows
If you see:
'python' is not recognized as an internal or external command
or
'py' is not recognized...
Try:

Restarting your computer.

Running the installer again and making sure “Add Python to PATH” is checked.

title: Setting Up Python
text:
Scripts not finding data files
Make sure:

Your .py script and your data files are in the same folder, or

Your script uses the correct relative path, like:

import pandas as pd

df = pd.read_csv("data/housing_prices.csv")
If you move files around, update the paths accordingly.
